paragraphs: May 2021Most people think of nerds as quiet, diffident people. In ordinary social situations they are — as quiet and diffident as the star quarterback would be if he found himself in the middle of a physics symposium.

And for the same reason: they are fish out of water. But the apparent diffidence of nerds is an illusion due to the fact that when non-nerds observe them, it's usually in ordinary social situations. In fact some nerds are quite fierce.The fierce nerds are a small but interesting group.

They are as a rule extremely competitive — more competitive, I'd say, than highly competitive non-nerds. Competition is more personal for them. Partly perhaps because they're not emotionally mature enough to distance themselves from it, but also because there's less randomness in the kinds of competition they engage in, and they are thus more justified in taking the results personally.Fierce nerds also tend to be somewhat overconfident, especially when young.

It might seem like it would be a disadvantage to be mistaken about one's abilities, but empirically it isn't. Up to a point, confidence is a self-fullfilling prophecy.Another quality you find in most fierce nerds is intelligence.

Not all nerds are smart, but the fierce ones are always at least moderately so. If they weren't, they wouldn't have the confidence to be fierce. [1]There's also a natural connection between nerdiness and independent-mindedness.

It's hard to be independent-minded without being somewhat socially awkward, because conventional beliefs are so often mistaken, or at least arbitrary. No one who was both independent-minded and ambitious would want to waste the effort it takes to fit in.

And the independent-mindedness of the fierce nerds will obviously be of the aggressive rather than the passive type: they'll be annoyed by rules, rather than dreamily unaware of them.I'm less sure why fierce nerds are impatient, but most seem to be.

You notice it first in conversation, where they tend to interrupt you. This is merely annoying, but in the more promising fierce nerds it's connected to a deeper impatience about solving problems. Perhaps the competitiveness and impatience of fierce nerds are not separate qualities, but two manifestations of a single underlying drivenness.When you combine all these qualities in sufficient quantities, the result is quite formidable.

The most vivid example of fierce nerds in action may be James Watson's The Double Helix. The first sentence of the book is "I have never seen Francis Crick in a modest mood," and the portrait he goes on to paint of Crick is the quintessential fierce nerd: brilliant, socially awkward, competitive, independent-minded, overconfident.

But so is the implicit portrait he paints of himself. Indeed, his lack of social awareness makes both portraits that much more realistic, because he baldly states all sorts of opinions and motivations that a smoother person would conceal.

And moreover it's clear from the story that Crick and Watson's fierce nerdiness was integral to their success. Their independent-mindedness caused them to consider approaches that most others ignored, their overconfidence allowed them to work on problems they only half understood (they were literally described as "clowns" by one eminent insider), and their impatience and competitiveness got them to the answer ahead of two other groups that would otherwise have found it within the next year, if not the next several months.

[2]The idea that there could be fierce nerds is an unfamiliar one not just to many normal people but even to some young nerds. Especially early on, nerds spend so much of their time in ordinary social situations and so little doing real work that they get a lot more evidence of their awkwardness than their power.

So there will be some who read this description of the fierce nerd and realize "Hmm, that's me." And it is to you, young fierce nerd, that I now turn.I have some good news, and some bad news. The good news is that your fierceness will be a great help in solving difficult problems.

And not just the kind of scientific and technical problems that nerds have traditionally solved. As the world progresses, the number of things you can win at by getting the right answer increases. Recently getting rich became one of them: 7 of the 8 richest people in America are now fierce nerds.Indeed, being a fierce nerd is probably even more helpful in business than in nerds' original territory of scholarship.

Fierceness seems optional there. Darwin for example doesn't seem to have been especially fierce. Whereas it's impossible to be the CEO of a company over a certain size without being fierce, so now that nerds can win at business, fierce nerds will increasingly monopolize the really big successes.The bad news is that if it's not exercised, your fierceness will turn to bitterness, and you will become an intellectual playground bully: the grumpy sysadmin, the forum troll, the hater, the shooter down of new ideas.How do you avoid this fate?

Work on ambitious projects. If you succeed, it will bring you a kind of satisfaction that neutralizes bitterness. But you don't need to have succeeded to feel this; merely working on hard projects gives most fierce nerds some feeling of satisfaction.

And those it doesn't, it at least keeps busy. [3]Another solution may be to somehow turn off your fierceness, by devoting yourself to meditation or psychotherapy or something like that. Maybe that's the right answer for some people.

I have no idea. But it doesn't seem the optimal solution to me. If you're given a sharp knife, it seems to me better to use it than to blunt its edge to avoid cutting yourself.If you do choose the ambitious route, you'll have a tailwind behind you.

There has never been a better time to be a nerd. In the past century we've seen a continuous transfer of power from dealmakers to technicians — from the charismatic to the competent — and I don't see anything on the horizon that will end it.

At least not till the nerds end it themselves by bringing about the singularity.Notes[1] To be a nerd is to be socially awkward, and there are two distinct ways to do that: to be playing the same game as everyone else, but badly, and to be playing a different game.

The smart nerds are the latter type.[2] The same qualities that make fierce nerds so effective can also make them very annoying. Fierce nerds would do well to remember this, and (a) try to keep a lid on it, and (b) seek out organizations and types of work where getting the right answer matters more than preserving social harmony.

In practice that means small groups working on hard problems. Which fortunately is the most fun kind of environment anyway.[3] If success neutralizes bitterness, why are there some people who are at least moderately successful and yet still quite bitter?

Because people's potential bitterness varies depending on how naturally bitter their personality is, and how ambitious they are: someone who's naturally very bitter will still have a lot left after success neutralizes some of it, and someone who's very ambitious will need proportionally more success to satisfy that ambition.So the worst-case scenario is someone who's both naturally bitter and extremely ambitious, and yet only moderately successful.
Thanks to Trevor Blackwell, Steve Blank, Patrick Collison, Jessica Livingston, Amjad Masad, and Robert Morris for reading drafts of this.Chinese Translation

paragraphs.original: May 2021Most people think of nerds as quiet, diffident people. In ordinary social situations they are — as quiet and diffident as the star quarterback would be if he found himself in the middle of a physics symposium.
paragraphs.translated: 2021年5月大多数人认为书呆子是安静、不自信的人。在普通的社交场合中，他们确实如此——就像明星四分卫发现自己置身于物理学研讨会中时一样安静和不自信。

paragraphs.original: And for the same reason: they are fish out of water. But the apparent diffidence of nerds is an illusion due to the fact that when non-nerds observe them, it's usually in ordinary social situations. In fact some nerds are quite fierce.The fierce nerds are a small but interesting group.
paragraphs.translated: 出于同样的原因：他们像鱼儿离开了水。但书呆子表面上的怯懦其实是一种错觉，因为当非书呆子观察他们时，通常是在普通的社交场合。事实上，有些书呆子相当凶猛。这些凶猛的书呆子虽然人数不多，却是一个有趣的群体。

paragraphs.original: They are as a rule extremely competitive — more competitive, I'd say, than highly competitive non-nerds. Competition is more personal for them. Partly perhaps because they're not emotionally mature enough to distance themselves from it, but also because there's less randomness in the kinds of competition they engage in, and they are thus more justified in taking the results personally.Fierce nerds also tend to be somewhat overconfident, especially when young.
paragraphs.translated: 他们通常极具竞争力——我认为，比那些极具竞争力的非书呆子更加竞争激烈。对他们来说，竞争更加个人化。部分原因可能是他们情感上还不够成熟，无法与竞争保持距离，但另一个原因是他们参与的竞争类型中随机性较少，因此他们更有理由将结果视为个人的。激烈的书呆子还往往有些过于自信，尤其是在年轻的时候。

paragraphs.original: It might seem like it would be a disadvantage to be mistaken about one's abilities, but empirically it isn't. Up to a point, confidence is a self-fullfilling prophecy.Another quality you find in most fierce nerds is intelligence.
paragraphs.translated: 看似对自己能力的误判会是个劣势，但实证研究表明并非如此。在一定范围内，自信是一种自我实现的预言。另一个你在大多数激烈的书呆子中会发现的品质是智力。

paragraphs.original: Not all nerds are smart, but the fierce ones are always at least moderately so. If they weren't, they wouldn't have the confidence to be fierce. [1]There's also a natural connection between nerdiness and independent-mindedness.
paragraphs.translated: 并非所有书呆子都聪明，但那些凶猛的书呆子至少是中等聪明的。如果他们不聪明，就不会有足够的自信去表现得凶猛。书呆子气和独立思考之间也存在着天然的联系。

paragraphs.original: It's hard to be independent-minded without being somewhat socially awkward, because conventional beliefs are so often mistaken, or at least arbitrary. No one who was both independent-minded and ambitious would want to waste the effort it takes to fit in.
paragraphs.translated: 想要独立思考而不显得有些社交awkward是很困难的，因为传统观念往往错误，或者至少是武断的。任何一个既独立思考又雄心勃勃的人都不会愿意浪费精力去迎合他人。

paragraphs.original: And the independent-mindedness of the fierce nerds will obviously be of the aggressive rather than the passive type: they'll be annoyed by rules, rather than dreamily unaware of them.I'm less sure why fierce nerds are impatient, but most seem to be.
paragraphs.translated: 而那些有独立思想的激烈书呆子显然会表现出积极而非消极的反抗：他们会对规则感到烦躁，而不是漠然不知。我不太确定为什么激烈的书呆子会不耐烦，但大多数人确实如此。

paragraphs.original: You notice it first in conversation, where they tend to interrupt you. This is merely annoying, but in the more promising fierce nerds it's connected to a deeper impatience about solving problems. Perhaps the competitiveness and impatience of fierce nerds are not separate qualities, but two manifestations of a single underlying drivenness.When you combine all these qualities in sufficient quantities, the result is quite formidable.
paragraphs.translated: 你首先会在对话中注意到这一点，他们往往会打断你。这仅仅是令人烦恼，但在那些更有潜力的激烈书呆子身上，这种行为与更深层次的解决问题的不耐烦有关。也许，激烈书呆子的竞争性和不耐烦并不是独立的特质，而是单一内在驱动力的两种表现。当这些特质以足够的量结合在一起时，其结果相当 formidable（ formidable 在这里可以译为“ formidable ”，但为了更自然的表达，可以译为“强大”）。

paragraphs.original: The most vivid example of fierce nerds in action may be James Watson's The Double Helix. The first sentence of the book is "I have never seen Francis Crick in a modest mood," and the portrait he goes on to paint of Crick is the quintessential fierce nerd: brilliant, socially awkward, competitive, independent-minded, overconfident.
paragraphs.translated: 最生动的例子可能是詹姆斯·沃森的《双螺旋》。这本书的开头是：“我从未见过弗朗西斯·克里克有谦逊的时候”，随后他对克里克的描绘堪称典型的强硬书呆子：才华横溢、社交笨拙、竞争激烈、思想独立、自信过头。

paragraphs.original: But so is the implicit portrait he paints of himself. Indeed, his lack of social awareness makes both portraits that much more realistic, because he baldly states all sorts of opinions and motivations that a smoother person would conceal.
paragraphs.translated: 但他对自己所描绘的隐含肖像也是如此。事实上，他缺乏社交意识使这两幅肖像更加真实，因为他坦率地表达了各种观点和动机，而一个更为圆滑的人则会掩饰这些。

paragraphs.original: And moreover it's clear from the story that Crick and Watson's fierce nerdiness was integral to their success. Their independent-mindedness caused them to consider approaches that most others ignored, their overconfidence allowed them to work on problems they only half understood (they were literally described as "clowns" by one eminent insider), and their impatience and competitiveness got them to the answer ahead of two other groups that would otherwise have found it within the next year, if not the next several months.
paragraphs.translated: 此外，从这个故事中可以明显看出，克里克和沃森的强烈书生气是他们成功的关键。他们的独立思考使他们考虑了大多数其他人忽视的方法，他们的过度自信使他们能够在只懂一半的问题上进行研究（一位著名的内部人士实际上称他们为“小丑”），而他们的急躁和竞争意识使他们比另外两个小组更早找到了答案，否则这些小组可能在接下来的一年，甚至几个月内就会发现。

paragraphs.original: [2]The idea that there could be fierce nerds is an unfamiliar one not just to many normal people but even to some young nerds. Especially early on, nerds spend so much of their time in ordinary social situations and so little doing real work that they get a lot more evidence of their awkwardness than their power.
paragraphs.translated: [2]认为书呆子中也可能有强者，这个想法不仅对许多普通人来说很陌生，甚至对一些年轻的书呆子来说也是如此。尤其是在早期，书呆子们大部分时间都在普通的社交场合中度过，真正投入工作的时间很少，因此他们得到的更多的是关于自己社交笨拙的证据，而非他们实力的证明。

paragraphs.original: So there will be some who read this description of the fierce nerd and realize "Hmm, that's me." And it is to you, young fierce nerd, that I now turn.I have some good news, and some bad news. The good news is that your fierceness will be a great help in solving difficult problems.
paragraphs.translated: 所以会有一些人读到对这个激烈的书呆子的描述，然后意识到“嗯，那就是我。”现在我要转向你，年轻的激烈书呆子。我有一些好消息，也有一些坏消息。好消息是，你的激烈将对解决难题大有帮助。

paragraphs.original: And not just the kind of scientific and technical problems that nerds have traditionally solved. As the world progresses, the number of things you can win at by getting the right answer increases. Recently getting rich became one of them: 7 of the 8 richest people in America are now fierce nerds.Indeed, being a fierce nerd is probably even more helpful in business than in nerds' original territory of scholarship.
paragraphs.translated: 这不仅仅是那些书呆子们历来解决的科学和技术问题。随着世界的进步，通过找到正确答案而能够获胜的事情越来越多。最近，致富也成为了其中之一：美国最富有的8个人中有7个是十足的书呆子。事实上，成为一个十足的书呆子在商业上可能比在书呆子们最初擅长的学术领域更有帮助。

paragraphs.original: Fierceness seems optional there. Darwin for example doesn't seem to have been especially fierce. Whereas it's impossible to be the CEO of a company over a certain size without being fierce, so now that nerds can win at business, fierce nerds will increasingly monopolize the really big successes.The bad news is that if it's not exercised, your fierceness will turn to bitterness, and you will become an intellectual playground bully: the grumpy sysadmin, the forum troll, the hater, the shooter down of new ideas.How do you avoid this fate?
paragraphs.translated: 凶悍似乎在那里是可选的。比如达尔文似乎并不是特别凶悍。然而，要在一定规模以上的公司担任首席执行官，不凶悍是不可能的，所以现在书呆子能在商界取得成功，凶悍的书呆子将越来越多地垄断真正的大成功。坏消息是，如果你不锻炼自己的凶悍，它会变成怨恨，你就会成为一个智力游乐场上的恶霸：爱发牢骚的系统管理员，论坛喷子，憎恨者，新想法的打击者。你如何避免这样的命运？

paragraphs.original: Work on ambitious projects. If you succeed, it will bring you a kind of satisfaction that neutralizes bitterness. But you don't need to have succeeded to feel this; merely working on hard projects gives most fierce nerds some feeling of satisfaction.
paragraphs.translated: 投身于雄心勃勃的项目。如果你成功了，这会带给你一种能够中和苦涩的满足感。但你无需成功就能感受到这种满足；仅仅是在困难的项目上工作，就能让大多数执着的书呆子感到某种满足。

paragraphs.original: And those it doesn't, it at least keeps busy. [3]Another solution may be to somehow turn off your fierceness, by devoting yourself to meditation or psychotherapy or something like that. Maybe that's the right answer for some people.
paragraphs.translated: 而对于那些它不能解决的问题，至少也能让你忙个不停。[3]另一种解决方法可能是以某种方式减弱你的激烈情绪，比如通过冥想、心理治疗等手段。也许这对某些人来说是正确的答案。

paragraphs.original: I have no idea. But it doesn't seem the optimal solution to me. If you're given a sharp knife, it seems to me better to use it than to blunt its edge to avoid cutting yourself.If you do choose the ambitious route, you'll have a tailwind behind you.
paragraphs.translated: 我不知道。但在我看来，这似乎不是最佳解决方案。如果你有一把锋利的刀，我觉得最好还是用它，而不是为了防止割伤自己而让它变钝。如果你选择雄心勃勃的道路，你将会有顺风助力。

paragraphs.original: There has never been a better time to be a nerd. In the past century we've seen a continuous transfer of power from dealmakers to technicians — from the charismatic to the competent — and I don't see anything on the horizon that will end it.
paragraphs.translated: 现在成为书呆子的时机再好不过了。在过去的一个世纪里，我们见证了权力从交易者向技术人员的持续转移——从富有魅力的人转向能力更强的人——而我看不到有任何迹象会终结这一趋势。

paragraphs.original: At least not till the nerds end it themselves by bringing about the singularity.Notes[1] To be a nerd is to be socially awkward, and there are two distinct ways to do that: to be playing the same game as everyone else, but badly, and to be playing a different game.
paragraphs.translated: 至少在极客们自己通过引发奇点来终结这一切之前。注[1] 成为一个极客意味着社交上笨拙，而要做到这一点有两种截然不同的方式：一种是和大家玩同样的游戏，但玩得很差；另一种是玩不同的游戏。

paragraphs.original: The smart nerds are the latter type.[2] The same qualities that make fierce nerds so effective can also make them very annoying. Fierce nerds would do well to remember this, and (a) try to keep a lid on it, and (b) seek out organizations and types of work where getting the right answer matters more than preserving social harmony.
paragraphs.translated: 聪明的书呆子属于后者。[2] 让书呆子如此有效的那些特质，也可能让他们变得非常令人反感。激烈的书呆子最好记住这一点，并且（a）努力克制自己，（b）寻找那些正确答案比保持社交和谐更重要的组织和工作类型。

paragraphs.original: In practice that means small groups working on hard problems. Which fortunately is the most fun kind of environment anyway.[3] If success neutralizes bitterness, why are there some people who are at least moderately successful and yet still quite bitter?
paragraphs.translated: 实际上，这意味着小团队致力于解决难题。幸运的是，这本身就是最有趣的工作环境。[3] 如果成功能消除怨恨，为什么有些至少算是中等成功的人仍然非常怨恨？

paragraphs.original: Because people's potential bitterness varies depending on how naturally bitter their personality is, and how ambitious they are: someone who's naturally very bitter will still have a lot left after success neutralizes some of it, and someone who's very ambitious will need proportionally more success to satisfy that ambition.So the worst-case scenario is someone who's both naturally bitter and extremely ambitious, and yet only moderately successful.
paragraphs.translated: 因为人们的潜在苦涩感取决于他们的性格天生有多苦涩以及他们有多雄心勃勃：一个天生非常苦涩的人即使在成功消解了一些苦涩之后仍然会有许多残留，而一个非常有雄心的人则需要成比例更多的成功来满足这种雄心。所以最糟糕的情况就是一个人既天生非常苦涩又极其雄心勃勃，但成功的程度却只是中等。
